sections.name: Identifying Information
sections.promptInstructions:
First Paragraph: (Center Align)
Confidential Multidisciplinary Report(Heading2)
This report is to be interpreted and used only by individuals properly trained and certified by state agencies and/or by parents or legal guardians of the stated child. This report is confidential and must not be released to persons who do not have a legitimate professional interest in the child.(Italic Style, Center Align)

Second Paragraph:
Title: Identifying Information (SectionHeading1)

And then there is a table with two columns, six rows. table must has grid lines.
Table Width: 100% Table border style: collapse
If given parameter is "(NOT PROVIDED)", don't write this parameter, only parameter, except date of report field.
In date of report field, write actual current date that formats like MM/DD/YYYY.

1st Row:
Student: (name), School: (school)
2nd Row:
Birth Date: (dateOfBirth)(format: MM/DD/YYYY), Parent/Guardian: (guardian)
3rd Row:
Chronological Age: (years) years (months) months, Multi-Disciplinary Team: RSP Teacher, School Psychologist
4th Row:
Primary Language: (language), Evaluation Dates: (eval_date)
5th Row:
Grade: (grade), Psychologist: Alexis E.Carter
6th Row:
Date of Report: ()(This field is current date.), Assessment: (assessment)

Each Box title: Bold

Report Information (SectionHeading2)
Reports Written by: (SubTitle)
School Psychologist (SP): Alexis E. Carter M.S. NCSP

sections.name: Purpose of Assessment
sections.promptInstructions:
Purpose of Assessment (SectionHeading2)

First Paragraph:
The purpose for (NAME)’s triennial review was to assess (NAME)’s continued eligibility for special education services. This report is a re-evaluation of (NAME)’s educational program, and this current assessment will help in determining whether: (NAME)’s continues to manifest a disability, to evaluate (NAME)’s present levels of educational functioning, as well as, to evaluate whether the continuation of special education services or related services are required for (NAME)’s educational success.

Second Paragraph:
The objectives of the current evaluation are to: (This Sentence is SubTitle)
Below are ordered lists.
1. Provide information on (NAME)’s present levels of performance, including (NAME)’s strengths and weaknesses.
2. Help determine whether (NAME) continues to meet the California Education Code criteria for an individual with exceptional needs,
3. Evaluate whether (NAME)’s current educational program is the least restrictive environment that can provide (NAME) with a free and appropriate public education.
4. Make recommendations to the Individualized Education Program team related to any program changes that may be appropriate based on (NAME)’s assessed educational needs..

sections.name: Validity Statement
sections.promptInstructions:
Validity Statement (SectionHeading2)

Paragraph:(Italic Style)
Environmental, cultural, or economic variables would not appear to be playing a significant role in learning difficulties. These observations, combined with adequate test taking behavior, lead the Examiner to conclude that this assessment offers a valid and reliable estimate of (NAME)’s learning skills and abilities. This evaluation was conducted by qualified personnel. Test and assessment materials, and procedures used for the purposes of assessment and placement of individuals with exceptional needs were selected and administered as not to be racially, culturally, or sexually discriminatory. The student's primary language combined with the examiner’s awareness of (NAME)’s cultural and ethnic background was taken into consideration.  Nonverbal instruments were also utilized if appropriate.

sections.name: Assessment Information
sections.promptInstructions:
Accessment Information (SectionHeading2)

First Paragraph:
Test Procedures and Materials(SubTitle)
In accordance with Education Code 56320, the following was considered regarding the procedures and materials used during the present evaluation to ensure compliance with state and federal regulations: This evaluation was conducted by qualified personnel.  The pupil was assessed in areas related to the suspected disability. The assessment materials were selected as not to be racially, sexually, or culturally discriminatory. They were provided and administered in the student’s dominant language and/or non-verbally, and in accordance with the instructions provided by the producer of each test. Tests have been validated for the specific areas of educational need and not merely those that are designed to provide a single general intelligence quotient. The assessment results provided accurately reflect the student’s aptitude, achievement level, and/or any other factors the test purports to measure, and not the pupil’s impaired sensory, manual, or speaking skills. 

Second Paragraph:
Exclusionary Factors and Validity of Test and Observational Results(SubTitle)
The assessment team considers the student’s background in making eligibility and placement decisions. The potential impact of environmental, cultural/lifestyle or economic factors have been considered.  

Third Paragraph: (This is only for the student that language is English)
Cultural and Linguistic Factors(This must follow style that Bold Style, Left Align, h4 tag, Uppercase, Underline)
Cultural and linguistic factors were considered during the selection of test materials for this evaluation. There appears to be no evidence of cultural, linguistic, or educational disadvantage. The Spanish language is the language spoken in the home. The most recent administration of English Language Proficiency Assessments for California (ELPAC) on (XX/XX/XX) which
identified (NAME) as an English Language Learner who is performing at an overall moderately developed level (X) of acquiring the English Language. The summative ELPAC scores measures how well students are learning the English language and help with determining the supports needed for the student to acquire the English language proficiently. Students who are at a level (X) in English language performance is able to use the English language to learn new
educational concepts.

Forth Paragraph:
Validity of Test Results(SubTitle)
Assessment materials and procedures utilized in the current evaluation were administered so as not to be racially, culturally, or sexually discriminatory. All tests have been validated for the specific purpose for which they were used (including low incidence) and administered by properly trained and credentialed personnel in accordance with test administration instructions. (NAME) was assessed in all areas related to (NAME) suspected disability.

sections.name: Background Information
sections.promptInstructions:
Background Information (SectionHeading1)
Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline, Left Align)
First Paragraph:
Developmental and Health History
Prompt:
Write one six sentence paragraph summarizing (NAME)'s Developmental and health history rite one six sentence paragraph summarizing (NAME) 's Developmental and health history please make sure that you identify information that relays when name was born, if there were any difficulties during childbirth or pregnancy, gnosis that the student may have, any medical conditions that the student may have, any developmental condition that the student may have, the student weighed when they were born, when and where did they receive treatment in any other facility besides the school, place the names of the facilities and the people who have done previous evaluations of the student, relay dates and times when the student was evaluated if evaluated outside of the school setting, and the student developmental age in months when the student had completed or did not complete developmental milestones. Create a visual chart of the students developmental abilities according to their months for when they started key point developmental milestones up to age 5. Please include in the chart if it is considered a concern or not based on the each developmental milestone. Please pull information from the document attached based on the mom’s, dad, grandparent’s, or guardian’s responses that will answer the questions below:
- Does your child wear glasses, and if so, do they bring them to evaluation sessions?
- When was the last time your child had their hearing and vision checked?
- Does your child currently take any medication? If yes, provide the name and purpose of the medication.
- Has your child suffered any severe physical or mental injury? If yes, specify the date and circumstances.
- Does your child have any current mental or physical health diagnoses (e.g., ADHD, autism, diabetes)?
- Was your child born from a normal pregnancy gestation? If yes, how many weeks did you carry the child?
- Were there any pregnancy complications? If yes, specify the type of complications.
- Did the baby go home from the hospital with the mother? If not, explain why.
- At what ages did your child achieve the following milestones: sitting independently, crawling, walking alone, first words, speaking in sentences, and toilet training?
- What age was your child fully toilet-trained?

Second Paragraph:
Home Background
Prompt:
Write one six sentence paragraph summarizing (NAME)'s background in the home environment. Please pull information from the document attached based on the mom's, dad, grandparent's, or guardian's responses that will answer the questions below:
- How does your child get along with family members?
- Who lives in your child's home (e.g., parents, grandparents, siblings, guardians)?
- Does your child have siblings? If yes, how many and what are their ages?
- Does (NAME) lives with his biological parents, if not? Why not?
- Are there any significant stressors in your child's life?

Third Paragraph:
Hearing and Vision Results

Hearing Results
Date: ()
Result: (PASS/FAIL)
Vision Results
Date: ()
Result: (PASS/FAIL)
Prompt:
Please fill the abovebrackets. Please create a three to four sentence paragraph on the (NAME)'s hearing and vision results and relay the date in which the student got their hearing completed and the results of that hearing screening and relay the dates for the vision screening and the results for the vision screening and any information necessary needed for any evaluation that was done outside of
the school environment. Please provide only the month and the year on which the hearing and or screening took place. Also include if the results would interfere with testing at the current moment. . Please pull information from the document attached based on the mom’s responses that will answer the questions below: Please pull information from the document attached based
on the mom’s, dad, grandparent’s, or guardian’s responses that will answer the questions below:
- Does your child wear glasses, and if so, do they wear them consistently during class?

sections.name: Academic History
sections.promptInstructions:
Academic History (SectionHeading1)
Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline Style, Left Align)
Prompt:
Attached file Content: (file)
Write one 5 sentence paragraph About (NAME)'s Academic history, Attendance history, Behavioral And social emotional history in the school setting. Please create a chart to show all current grades reports and previous grade reports, please create a chart showing any disciplinary record, if any please relay what the students academic history based on the grade report attendance and their disciplinary history is relying on how the student is able to function and acquire the curriculum in the school setting or an educational setting. Please pull information from the document attached that will answer the questions below:
- Does the student have a disciplinary history? If so, what were the disciplinary actions, and on what dates did these actions take place? Where did these disciplinary actions occur?
- Does the student have a history of not attending school? If not, what does their attendance history indicate?
- What do the student’s grades reveal about their ability to complete academic work?
- What is the history of the student’s schooling? Which schools has the student attended, and which school are they currently enrolled in?

Please pull information from the document attached that will answer the questions below:
- Does the student have a disciplinary history? If so, what were the disciplinary actions, and on what dates did these actions take place? Where did these disciplinary actions occur?

sections.name: Teacher Interview
sections.promptInstructions:
Teacher Interview (SubTitle)
Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline Style, Left Align)
Prompt:
Attached File: (FILE)
Write one six sentence paragraph about (NAME)'s teacher's interview, Write one six sentence paragraph about (NAME)'s teacher's interview, please relay any positive characteristics that the teacher has relayed about the student. Please relay any negative characteristics that the teacher has relayed about the student. Please relay any details about the students’ difficulties when it comes to academics and when it comes to social skills and social emotional health, please relay the concerns of the teacher. Please include what the student can or cannot do academically and with communication please be specific in the areas in which the teacher identify and what in what the student can actually do or cannot do based on the information provided. please analyze the information and relay how this information relays about . Please pull information from the document attached based on the teacher’s responses that will answer the questions below:
- What is the student's consistency in completing assignments, and does this vary by subject?
- How does the student follow directions when turning in assignments?
- How would you describe the student’s participation in group or class work, and any reluctance to contribute?
- What are the student’s observable work habits, and are there any notable inconsistencies?
- How attentive is the student to class subject matter, and does attentiveness vary by subject?
- How would you assess the student's motivation and performance in relation to their ability level?
- What is the student's general behavior in class, and how often do they need redirection?
- How does the student interact with peers, and do any issues impact their ability to meet objectives?
- What are the student's current levels of performance in reading, including fluency and strategies?
- What are the student’s abilities and challenges in writing, including vocabulary and organization?
- How would you describe the student’s math skills, both computational and reasoning?
- What are the student’s communication skills, including strengths and difficulties?

sections.name: Behavioral Observations
sections.promptInstructions:
Behavioral Observations(SectionHeading1)
Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline Style, Left Align)

First Paragraph:
Evaluation Observation

(NAME) was observed, for a total of 95 minutes, during the assessment evaluation on (DATE). Rapport was easily built between (NAME) and the examiner. (NAME) properly attended to each test item.  The examiner frequently checked for understanding which (NAME) would respond by shaking (HIS/HER) head and stating “no” or “yes” that she understood.   During the assessment, the examiner relayed the test questions by using hand signals, pantomimes, and Basic English instruction.  (NAME) followed all instructions. While in the assessment session, (NAME) sat in (HIS/HER) seat with (HIS/HER) shoulders in a relaxed state. (HE/SHE) cooperated with all instruction relayed to (HIM/HER) by the examiner.

Second Paragraph:
Classroom Observations by special education teacher

Prompt: Write one six sentence paragraph about (NAME)’s Observations and please relay all of the dates, and collaborative minutes in which the observation took place, as well as, which setting the observations took place in. Please relay how many students were in the classroom during the observation, where the students sat at during the observation. What the students were working on or we’re engaged in when the observation was taking place, please relay all behaviors positive and or negative behaviors that was identified during the observation. Please create an analysis on if the behavior is observed or considered typical for the environment or if they were considered problematic for the environment. Relate an analysis on if the student was observed exhibiting appropriate social skills or if they or if they were not exhibited appropriate social skills, as well as if they had exhibited the appropriate facial affect for the environment that they were in their behaviors in that setting beneficial to their learning or hindering their learning ability in that setting Based on the information provided.

Third Paragraph:
Social Observation completed by Special Education Teacher

Prompt: Write one six sentence paragraph about (NAME)’s Observations and please relay all of the dates, and collaborative minutes in which the observation took place, as well as, which setting the observations took place in. Please relate if the student was observed exhibiting behaviors that include the behaviors below: Overreliance on scripting or repetitive phrases during interactions with peers or Limited participation in group discussions or reluctance to speak in front of the class. Trouble asking for help or clarifying instructions independently. Struggles with understanding abstract or figurative language used in lessons.Preference for working alone, avoiding group activities or peer collaboration.Difficulty initiating or maintaining conversations with classmates.Limited engagement during peer-based learning or cooperative tasks.Difficulty transitioning between activities or subjects, often leading to frustration or anxiety.Difficulty sitting
still or remaining seated due to sensory seeking or avoidance. Unusual responses to textures, such as resistance to certain materials or classroom supplies.Need for sensory breaks or tools (e.g., noise-canceling headphones, fidget toys). Difficulty processing multiple sensory inputs simultaneously (e.g., listening to a lecture while taking notes).Difficulty with multi-step directions or tasks without clear, visual steps.Over-reliance on teacher prompts to complete work. Challenges with generalization, requiring explicit instruction to apply skills to new contexts. Focus on details rather than the overall concept, leading to misunderstandings in assignments. Difficulty interpreting peer behavior, leading to misunderstandings or conflicts. Overattachment to specific adults or peers, creating challenges in independence. Resistance to correction or redirection from teachers or peers. Lack of awareness of how behaviors (e.g., interrupting)
impact the learning environment. Avoidance of eye contact or other typical social signals during communication. On the information provided.

sections.name: Current Assessment Results and Interpretation
sections.promptInstructions:
Current Assessment Results And Interpretation (SectionHeading1, font Underline Style)
Performance levels for most tests administered will be reported according to the following scale:

And then there is table with 4 columns, head row and five rows.
Each field has single border and align center, table border style is collapse.
Head Row field Style: Bold, Uppercase, Center align, gray background

Head Row: Standard Score, Scaled Score, Percentile Rank, Performance Level
1st Row: 130+, 160+, >98, Superior
2nd Row: 116-130, 13-15, 85-97, Above Average
3rd Row: 85-115, 7-12, 16-84, Average
4th Row: 71-84, 4-6, 3-8, Below Average
5th Row: 70 and below, 3 and below, <3, Significantly Below Average

One exception to this classification scheme will be the behavioral rating scales, which use different performance level descriptors.(SubTitle)
 
The test results section is organized into the following areas:(This sentence is SubTitle Style)
Below are lists.
I.	Observations
II.	Functioning: Cognitive, Socio-emotional, Communication, and Physical Development
III.	Social Emotional Functioning
IV.	 Adaptive Behavior Functioning
V.	Specialty Rating Scale Functioning
VI.	Academic Functioning

sections.name: Cognitive Functioning Skills
sections.promptInstructions:
Cognitive Functioning Skills(SectionHeading1)

Prompt: Please create a score interpretation chart from the pdf document that was uploaded.please include the standard scores, the scaled scores, percentile, and the interpretation of if the scores is considered average (SS:85-114), below average (SS: 71-84), significantly below average (SS:55-70), and above average (SS:115-129) significantly above average (SS:130 and above).Write four five sentence paragraph and name the paragraphs and discuss and label Fulll Scale index for one paragraph, Pictorial scale index and discuss and label for one paragraph, and Geometric Scale index and discuss and label for one paragraph, please include (NAME)'s standard scores, scaled scores, percentiles, and classifications on the test of the student overall reasoning and problem solving abilities and what they indicate in regards to the student’s educational abilities based on the information below:

sections.name: Cognitive Functioning Skills-2nd Edition-2
sections.promptInstructions:
There are three paragraphs.

Paragraph: (p tag)
(NAME) was administered The Comprehensive Test of Nonverbal Intelligence, Second Edition (CTONI-2) to assess her overall reasoning abilities. (NAME) obtained a standard score of (XX) and a percentile of 3(XX)which places her in the Average range for the Pictorial Scale Index. The pictorial scale index measures her ability to use Analogical reasoning. Analogical reasoning
is any type of thinking that relies upon Analogy. An Analogical argument is an explicit representation of a form of Analogical reasoning that cites accepted similarities between two systems to support the conclusion that some further similarity exists. Something Analogical compares two different things. For example, an analogical expression might be "My house is so
cold it's like a refrigerator in here. "An Analogy is a comparison usually either a metaphor or a simile that helps to explain something or make it clearer. Analogical things use Analogies or refer to them. A comparison like "You are quiet as a mouse" or "My brother was a pig at dinner. Analogical reasoning is important to how a student performs in school because being able to use Analogical reasoning will support academic ability in reading, writing, math, and understanding social situations. Analogical reasoning helps students break down new information and relationships. (NAME) standard score on the Pictorial scale indicate that she is able to use appropriate reasoning abilities when given situations where she will need to compare the similarities of concrete and/or abstract concepts and/or ideas.

Paragraph: (p tag)
(NAME) obtained a standard score of XX and a percentile of XX which places her in the (AVERAGE/BELOW AVERAGE/SIGNIFICANTLY BELOW AVERAGE/ ABOVE
AVERAGE) range for the Geometric scale Index. The geometric scale index measures her ability to use categorical reasoning. Categorical Reasoning deals with the way students classify things. More specifically, it measures how students understand the relationship between certain categories or classes. cognitively. For example, a student comprehending and categorizing a question such as “Things that are cats but are not mammals” or “things that are cats and mammals”. The student will have to categorize the information to come to the appropriate answer which is that “All cats are mammals so there are no cats that are not mammals”. Categorical reasoning affects how a person groups information to be able to apply it to a problem
and/or situation. (NAME) standard scores on the geometric scale index indicate that she possesses the ability to use categorical reasoning when being presented with a situation where she may have to accumulate random, previously acquired, information and use it to solve a problem, and/or gain clarity on a situation that is presented to h.

Paragraph: (p tag)
The Comprehensive Test of Nonverbal Intelligence, Second Edition (CTONI-2) was administered only using non-verbal hand gestures and hand signals. No verbal communication was relayed to (NAME) during the administration of this measure to rule out any possible barriers created by (NAME)’s English language capabilities. The examinee possessed the option to use verbal language and/or hand gestures. (NAME) obtained a standard score of (XX) and a percentile of (XX) which places (HIM/HER) in the (AVERAGE/BELOW AVERAGE/SIGNIFICANTLY BELOW AVERAGE/ ABOVE AVERAGE) range for the full-scale Index. The full-scale index measures (NAME)’s overall ability to use and apply multiple reasoning skills towards an academic and/or social situation. (NAME) standard scores indicate that she is able to apply/struggles with applying multiple reasoning skills to address an academic and/or social situation appropriately.

sections.name: Cognitive Functioning Skills-5th Edition-1
sections.promptInstructions:
SubTitle: Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Fifth Edition (WISC-V)

The WISC-V is an individually administered clinical instrument for assessing the cognitive
ability of children aged 6 years through 16 years, 11 months.
(Readers are reminded that IQ tests do not measure every aspect of human intelligence. IQ tests are to be considered predictive estimates of future academic performance, and subsequent assessments may yield variable performance in measured skills. Other relevant factors that are not measured by IQ tests may include: motivation, attentiveness, self-discipline, competitiveness, compliance, etc. Readers are encouraged to consider the
influence of cultural factors and individual experience within mainstream culture when interpreting IQ test results).(Bold Style using Strong tag, Italic Style)
The WISC-V was administered by a trained telepractice school psychologist using a remote, high-quality HD HIPPA & FERPA compliant video conferencing platform. No significant technological problems were noted during administration. Modifications to the standardization procedure included: examinee utilized annotation tools to indicate selection versus traditional pointing or circling items with paper/pencil. The WISC-V
subtests have received initial validation in several samples for remote telepractice administration. Results are considered to be a valid estimate of examinee’s current skill functioning, aside from the impact of the aforementioned off-task behaviors observed. The WISC-V is an individually administered, comprehensive clinical instrument for assessing the
cognitive functioning of children ages 6:0 through 16:11. Assessment performance is compared to national age norms. Composite scores are represented as standard scores, whereas subtest scores are reported as scaled scores.

And then there is a table with 4 columns, head row, and 7 rows.
Table width: 100%, border collapse. Table's each field: Center align, Single Border.
Head Row: Standard Score Range, Description, Scaled Score Range, Description(Bold Style using Strong tag, gray background)
Each Rows are following:
1st Row: 130 and above, Extremely High, 16 to 19, Extremely High
2st Row: 120 to 129, Very High, 13 to 15, High
3rd Row: 110 to 119, High Average, 8-12, Average
4th Row: 90 to 109, Average, 5 to 7, Low
5th Row: 80 to 89, Low Average, 1 to 4, Extremely Low
6th Row: 70 to 79, Very Low
7th Row: 69 and below, Extremely Low
6*3, 6*4, 7*3, 7*4 Field: (Gray Background)

sections.name: Cognitive Functioning Skills-5th Edition-2
sections.promptInstructions:
Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children-Fifth Edition (WISC-V) (SubTitle, Underline)
And then there is a table with 4 columns, head row, and 17 rows.
Table width: 100%, border collapse. Table's each field: Center align, Single Border
Head Row: Composite/Subtest, Description, Standard Score/Scaled Score, Percentile Rank(Bold Style using Strong tag, gray background)
Each Rows are following:
1st Row: Veerbal Comprehension, Measures the breadth and depth of acquired knowledge, the ability to communicate that knowledge and the ability to reason using previously learned experiences or procedures.
2st Row: Similarities, Abstract,logical thinking,categorical thinking
3rd Row: Vocabulary, Word Knowledge from experience and lanugage background,long term memory.
4th Row: Fluid Reasoning, Measures the ability to reason,form concepts and solve problems usin unfamiliar information or novel procedures.
5th Row: Matrix Reasoning, Visual information processing,abstract reasoning
6th Row: Figure Weights, Measures quantitative fluid reasoning that can be expressed mathematically using an inductive or deductive logic.
7th Row: Working Memory, Measures capacity to hold information in the mind for a few seconds,process the information,and provide a response;attentional control
8th Row: Digit Span, Repeat a string of digits in forward and reverse order;mentally organize and repeat a string of digits in order from smallest to largest.
9th Row: Picture Span, View pictures presented in a linear fashion for a few seconds and then recall pictures previously seen on the following page.
10th Row: Non-Motor Visual Spatial, Provides insight into a child's visual-spatial abilities without the requirement of manipulation of physical, tangible items.
11th Row: Block Design Multiple Choice, View picctures of blocks arranged in a particular fashion and identify the set of blocks that would fit together to create the target picture.
12th Row: Visual Puzzles, visual and spatial reasoning,mental rotation,ability to analyze and synthesize abstract visual stimuli.
13th Row(Merged, One Column, Center Align): Ancillary Indices & Subtests
14th Row: Coding, Processing speed measure with motor component. Performance is related to visual scanning,visual discrimination,short-term visual memory,visuomotor coordination,and concentration.
15th Row: Naming Speed Index, Estimate of the student's basic naming ability and automaticity.
16th Row: Naming Speed Literacy, Rapid automatic naming.
17th Row: Naming Speed Quantity, Rapid automatic naming.
6th~12th*3~4 Field, 14th~17th*3~4 Field: (Gray Background)

sections.name: Cognitive Functioning Skills-5th Edition-3
sections.promptInstructions:
There are several paragraphs.

First Paragraph:

The Comprehension Knowledge (Verbal Comprehension) Index of the WISC-V included the Similarities and Vocabulary subtests. His overall performance on this index fell below age expectations. On the Similarities subtest, STUDENT was read two words that represented common objects or concepts and was asked to describe how they are similar. On this subtest, STUDENT  performed below age expectations. He often was able to indicate that the two objects/concepts were different, but could not describe ways in which they were similar. On the Vocabulary subtest, STUDENT was asked to define words read aloud by the examiner. His performance on this subtest also fell below age expectations. This composite is highly correlated with language-based and reading comprehension ability.

Second Paragraph:

The Fluid Reasoning Index consisted of the Matrix Reasoning and Figure Weights subtests. His overall performance on this index fell on the upper end of age expectations, nearly in the above average range. On the Matrix Reasoning subtest, STUDENT viewed an incomplete matrix or series and selected the response option that completed the matrix or series. On
this task, STUDENT performed on the higher end of age expectations. On the Figure Weights subtest, STUDENT viewed a scale with missing weight(s) and, within a specific time limit, selected the response option that kept the scale balanced. On this subtest, STUDENT also performed on the higher end of age expectations. This composite is highly correlated with problem-solving and mathematics ability.

Third Paragraph:

The Working Memory Index consisted of the Digit Span and Picture Span subtests. The Working Memory Index measures a child’s ability to hold information in his/her mind and then use it within a few seconds, as well as to attend to verbally or visually presented information, process that information in memory, and then to formulate a response. Attention, concentration, and mental control are important skills assessed within this
composite. On this index, STUDENT performed solidly within age expectations. On the Digit Span subtest, STUDENT was asked to listen to a string of digit read aloud by the examiner. He then had to repeat the digits in forward and reverse order. He then had to sequence the digits by mentally organizing them by smallest to largest, and then verbalize his response to the examiner. On this subtest, STUDENT performed within the average range when
compared to age expectations. On the Picture Span subtest, STUDENT was shown a group of objects presented in a linear fashion. He was asked to remember the pictures in order. A few seconds later, he was asked to identify the pictures, in order, that the examiner had just exposed. On this subtest, (NAME) performed within age expectations.

Forth Paragraph:

The Non-Motor Visual Spatial Index takes place of the standard Visual Spatial Index in this context due to remote administration. The Non-Motor Visual Spatial Index provides insight into a child’s visual-spatial abilities without the requirement of manipulation of physical, tangible items. Overall on this index, (NAME) performed within the average range for his age. Within this index, (NAME) was shown pictures of blocks that were arranged in a particular fashion and was asked to identify the set of blocks that would fit together to create the target picture of blocks. On this subtest, (NAME) performed within the average range when compared to age norms. On the Visual Puzzles subtest, (NAME) was shown a completed puzzle and was asked to select three individual shapes that would need to be put together/manipulated in order to create the target puzzle. On this subtest, (NAME) also performed within the average range based upon age norms.

Fifth Paragraph:

(NAME) was administered an additional subtest, the Coding subtest, in order to measure his processing speed with regard to paper-pencil tasks. He was asked to view a key which exemplified the mark associated with each pictured shape. He was then asked to view a set of empty shapes, and within a certain period of time, (NAME) was asked to draw the mark associated with each shape based upon the key. On this subtest, (NAME) worked at an adequate pace. His performance fell within the average range when compared to age norms.

Sixth Paragraph:

The Naming Speed Index provides an estimate of the (NAME)’s basic naming ability and automaticity. These tasks were developed to enhance the assessment of children with suspected learning challenges and are not designed as measures of intellectual ability. The two ancillary subtests that comprise this Index include the Naming Speed Literacy and Naming Speed Quantity subtests. Current evidence suggests that rapid automatic naming
measures significantly predict reading ability in both younger and older children with reading disabilities. On this index, (NAME)’s performance fell below the average range when compared to age norms.

Seventh Paragraph:

Overall, (NAME)’s Nonverbal General Ability Index score fell within the average range when compared to expectations for his age. However, consideration of his performance on individual indices and subtests suggests a profile of strengths and weaknesses. These cognitive weaknesses are empirically linked to the academic weaknesses (NAME) displayed on formal and informal assessment measures.

sections.name: TAPS-4(Auditory Processing)
sections.promptInstructions:
Auditory Processing (SectionHeading1)
Test of Auditory Processing Skills, 4th Edition (TAPS-4) (This is SubTitle Sytle.)

Note: Each Paragraph Title: (SubTitle)

Prompt:
Attached file content: (FILE)
Please create a score interpretation chart from the attached file content. please include the standard scores, the scaled scores, all percentile, and the interpretation of if the scores is considered average (SS:85-114), below average (SS: 71-84), significantly below average (SS:55-70), and above average (SS:115-129) significantly above average (SS:130 and above). In the chart, the standard scores and the scaled scores for that particular index should have their own column underneath their index. Write four five sentence paragraph and name the
paragraphs and discuss phonological processing index and include the scaled scores
Word Discrimination, Phonological Deletion, and the scaled score Phonological Blending for one paragraph, for auditory memory index for one paragraph and include the subscales Number Memory Forward, Word Memory, and Sentence Memory ,
and listening comprehension index including it’s sub scales for Processing Oral Directions, and Auditory Comprehension for one paragraph, and the overall auditory processing ability for one paragraph please include (NAME)’s standard scores, scaled scores, percentiles, and classifications on the test of auditory processing abilities and what they indicate in regards to his educational abilities based on the information below: Please include a narrative list at the bottom that indicate exactly how the student could use their strength in the classroom and how the student's weakness would hinder them in the classroom and identify the behaviors which the students would show that indicate a strength and or a weakness in the classroom based on the information presented.

And then there is a table with no border:
1st Row(Bold Style, Italic Style): Subtest Name, Description
2nd Row: Word Discrimination, Assesses the student’s ability to discern phonological differences and similarities within word pairs.
3rd Row: Phonological Deletion, Determines how well a student can manipulate phonemes within words.
4th Row: Phonological Blending, Assesses how well the student can synthesize a word given the various phonemes.
5th Row: Number Memory Forward, Examines how well the student can retain simple sequences of auditory information.
6th Row: Word Memory, Assesses how well the student can retain and manipulate
simple sequences of auditory information.
7th Row: Sentence Memory, Examines how well the student can retain details in sentences of increasing length and grammatical complexity.
8th Row: Auditory Comprehension, Designed to determine how well the student understands spoken information.
9th Row: Processing Oral Direction, Examines higher-order linguistic processing skills, which are related to understanding jokes, riddles, inferences and
abstractions.

sections.name: TAPS-4(Visual Processing)

Visual Processing (SectionHeading1)
Visual Processing is the ability to recognize and interpret visual stimuli involving the use of visual memory and visual sequencing. In involves two facets: [1] understanding/comprehending visual instruction and [2] remembering visually administered instruction from either rote and/or
retrieval and recall ability.(Italic Style)

Test of Auditory Processing Skills, 4th Edition (TAPS-4) (SubTitle)

for the subtest Visual discrimination, visual memory, and Spatial Relationships scaled scores, percentiles, and classification in one paragraph, Form Consistency, sequential memory, visual figure-ground, and visual closure for one paragraph, and the Overall Visual Processing abilities for one paragraph and include the standard scores, percentile, and classification, on the test of Visual processing abilities and what they indicate in regards to his educational abilities. sections.name: Sensory-Motor Integration
sections.promptInstructions:
Sensory-Motor Integration (SectionHeading1)
Beery-Buktenica Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration, 6th Edition (SubTitle)
The Beery-Buktenica Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration- 6 th Edition (VMI) is a standardized assessment instrument that provides an estimate of the developmental level of an individual’s visual-fine motor skills as required for the pencil-paper reproduction of a series of
increasingly complex designs. This test requires the student to copy figures such as a line, square, and circle as well as more difficult multi-dimensional items. According to the VMI manual, visual-motor integration is defined as, “the degree to which visual perception and finger-hand movements are well coordinated.” Performance on the VMI is described by a standard
score (with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15).

And then there is a table with headrow, 5 columns, and a row.
Table Border: Collapse, Each field: Single Border
Head Row(Center Align): Composite/Subtest, Description, Standard Score, Percentile, Descriptor
Row: Beery VMI, Requires the child to copy figures such as a line, square, and circles.

(NAME) obtained a standard score of XX and a percentile of XX which is considered in the Average/BELOW AVERAGE/SIGNIFICANTLY BELOW AVERAGE RANGE range on the Berry Buktenica Developmental Test of Visual-Motor Integration (VMI) test. (NAME)’s ability to view and recreate geometric shapes and designs of increasing difficulty is considered Average compared to peers of (HIS/HER) age and is not considered an area of strength for (HIM/HER).

sections.name: GARS-3-Parent
sections.promptInstructions:
Gilliam Autism Rating Scale, Third Edition (GARS-3) Parent: (SubTitle)
Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline Style)
Prompt:
Attached file content: (FILE)
Please create a score interpretation table with collapse border that includes both the parent and teacher form from the attached file content. write one five sentence paragraph on (NAME)’s Parent results on the Gilliam Autism Rating Scale, Third Edition (GARS-3). Write a paragraph relaying in which areas that his mother may or may not have observed her child exhibiting behaviors that are aligned with an Autism Spectrum Disorder and for which areas he was considered Unlikely which means he does not exhibit ASD 14 haracteristics, Probable meaning that there is
a possibility that he may be exhibiting specific ASD 14 haracteristics and/or Likely which indicate that based on the observer has has been observed exhibiting behaviors that align with an Autism Spectrum Behaviors. The ASD 14 haracteristics that are examined by this rating scale are : Restricted/Repetitive Behaviors may include stereotyped behaviors, or fixated interests, routines, or rituals., Social Interactions: refer to social behavior such as showing little or no interest in other people, not initiating conversations with others, and showing minimal
expressed pleasure with peers or others., Social Communication measures the individual’s responses to social situations and understanding of the intent of social interaction and communication.Emotional Responses measure extreme emotional responses to everyday situations.Cognitive Style measures idiosyncratic fixated interests, characteristics and cognitive abilities.The Maladaptive Speech subscale consists of items that describe deficits and idiosyncrasies in verbal communication. Based on the information where it shows that he is probable or likely to exhibit the specified characteristics that align with an ASD please relay how this can effect his abilities in the area of socio-emotional, though process, socio-emotional development, academically, and social skills and behaviors based on the information below:

Each Paragraph Title: (Bold, Underline Style)

characteristics and/or Likely which indicate that based on the observer has been observed exhibiting behaviors that align with an Autism Spectrum Behaviors. The ASD characteristics that are examined by this rating scale are: Restricted/Repetitive Behaviors may include stereotyped behaviors, or fixated interests, routines, or rituals., Social Interactions: refer to social behavior such as showing little or no interest in other people, not initiating conversations with others, and showing minimal expressed pleasure with peers or others., Social Communication measures the individual’s responses to social situations and understanding of the intent of social interaction and communication. Emotional Responses measure extreme emotional responses to everyday situations. Cognitive Style measures idiosyncratic fixated interests, characteristics and cognitive abilities. The Maladaptive Speech subscale consists of items that describe deficits and idiosyncrasies in verbal communication. Based on the information where it shows that the student is probable or likely to exhibit the specified characteristics that align with an ASD please relay how this can affect the students abilities in the educational settings in the area of socio-emotional, thought process, socio-emotional development, academically, and social skills and behaviors based on the information below:

sections.name: Summary And Diagnostic Impressions
sections.promptInstructions:
Summary And Diagnostic Impressions(SectionHeading1)
(NAME) is a (years) year (months) month old (grade) grade (gender) (MALE/FEMALE) student who currently attends (SCHOOL). (NAME)’s primary language is (LANGUAGE). she has been given an extensive battery, as part of a psycho-educational assessment to determine continued eligibility and most appropriate placement and services.

Prompt:
Write one 6 sentence paragraph About (NAME)'s results. please include the overall standard scores, percentile, and classification for each Overall Test area . please indicate what the standard scores mean regarding the student's educational functioning for each area based on (NAME)’s testing results on each test that include the information below:

Eligibility Considerations (SectionHeading1)
The decision as to whether or not the assessment results demonstrate that the degree of the pupil’s impairment requires special education services will be made by the individualized education program team at the IEP meeting scheduled to discuss the results of ther evaluation. No single score or product of scores, test or procedures will be used as the sole criterion for the decisions of the individualized education program team as to (NAME)’s eligibility for special education.

Specific Learning Disability (SubTitle, Underline)
The student exhibits a significant discrepancy between ability and achievement in the areas of (math calculation, math reasoning, reading comprehension, basic reading skills, written expression, listening comprehension, or oral expression) due to a processing disorder in
(attention, visual processing, auditory processing, sensory motor skills, conceptualization, expression and association), and is not primarily the result of environmental, cultural, economic disadvantage, or limited English proficiency.

It is the examiner’s opinion that based on academic history, assessment results, parent reports, and teacher reports, (NAME) meets/does not meet the eligibility criteria of specific learning disability. (NAME) has been assessed as having a psychological processing deficit in one or more of the following:

And then there is a table with 4 columns and 4 rows.
Table width: 100%, Table Border: collapse. Each field: Single Border
2nd Column: Attention, Visual Processing, Auditory Processing, Sensory Motor
4th Column: Cognitive Association, Cognitive Conceptualization, Cognitive Expression, None Exhibited

A serve discrepancy exists between cognitive ability and achievement in one or more of the following areas:

And then there is a table with 4 columns and 4 rows.
Table width: 100%, Table Border: collapse. Each field: Single Border
2nd Column: Oral Expression, Listening Comprehension, Written Expression, Basic Reading Skills
4th Column: Reading Comprehension, Mathematics Calculation, Mathematics Reasoning, None Exhibited

Recommendations (SubTitle)

1. The Individualized Education Program (IEP) team needs to review and consider the assessment results and recommendations of all team members.
2. When relaying instructions, relay separate tasks individually and wait to relay further instruction until (NAME) has completed the previous task
3. Check for understanding by having (NAME) repeat instructions back to the adult.
4. Provide visuals when relaying instructions verbally.
5. Include verbal praise for work completed.
6. Provide multiple breaks.
7. Providing guided notes and instruction in attending to relevant information
8. Using high-interest activities and hands-on demonstrations
9. Modifying in-class assignments and responses
10. Modifying homework
11. Highlighting relevant material or key information with colors, symbols, or font changes

basePrompt:
Here are defined font styles:
Heading1 => Bold Style, Center Align, h2 tag
Heading2 => Bold Style, Center Align, h3 tag
SectionHeading1 => Bold Style, Center Align, h4 Tag, border, Uppercase Font
SectionHeading2 => Bold Style, Center Align, h4 Tag, No border
SubTitle => Bold Style using strong tag, Left Align

Given the parameters, fill each fields using this in below sentences, and output the result html code(only body content).
